entry.title: Re: Customer stock in custody
entry.content:
Thanks once again dear Lakshmipathi!

Regarding the recommended approach, the material must be completely supplied out, because the material is invoiced and at that moment, our accounting books must show the total transfer of ownership, leaving the stock of that sale at 0, with nothing pending (so the first process must be ended performing the goods issue). This is not the doubt, the questions come after that process, and that's where the challenge comes in.

Regarding the ‚Äúcustomer plant‚Äù challenge, the process I heard about over the weekend is precisely we have an already created the sales order, delivery, goods issue, and invoice in SAP. Ownership has legally passed to the customer and then the stock is ‚Äúreceived‚Äù into a non‚Äëvaluated custody plant for visibility and when the customer asks later to physically ship them, a ‚ÄúDelivery free of charge sales order‚Äù must be created using the customer plant/storage location, so an outbound delivery can be created and complete then the physical supply performing the corresponding goods issue‚Ä¶ The process sound logic to me and I'm starting to think that if the sales scenario is as I described at the beginning, it seems to me there wouldn't be any options... but I still really appreciate having confirmation before requesting the creation of a customized "customer plant" as non-valued. If the described process is confirmed, my doubts are reduced to some few practical things, such as, once the material leaves the valued plant, how should be the customer stock entry into the non-valued plant be done... that is, only manually with MIGO? or is there a way to avoid doing it manually? When requesting the creation of the "customer plant" as non-valued, do I need to pay attention to anything regarding the Storage location that I assume should also be created? Finally, in the sales order "Delivery free of charge" type, I see several types of "item categories"... are there any suggested types or, conversely, any that are not recommended? Is there anything else to consider that I might be overlooking?

entry.title: Using Insights in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager ‚Äî Part 3 of a Series
entry.content:
How Insights Fit into SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager

For customers
Insights represent data-backed findings about how processes perform today, where bottlenecks exist, and where the greatest value potential lies.
SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager brings these insights together from process mining, benchmarking, documentation, and expert knowledge.
They form the evidence base used to:

  • identify opportunities
  • prioritize initiatives
  • assess value potential
  • track improvements over time

For partners
Insights create a foundation for integrated diagnostic and advisory solutions. Partners can use the platform‚Äôs APIs to:

  • embed insights from external analytics engines
  • push process mining findings directly into initiative planning
  • automate enrichment of transformation workspaces with benchmark and KPI data

This makes insights an essential layer for partner-built accelerators, methodologies, and assessments.

What an Insight Represents

An insight is not a fact for its own sake. It is a decision-enabling observation such as:

  • cycle time deviations
  • rework hotspots
  • compliance violations
  • best-practice gaps compared to industry peers
  • segments of a process with high variation
  • cost or value leakage points

In SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager, these signals are transformed into structured, reusable knowledge tied to objectives and initiatives.

How to Use Insights Effectively

  1. Establish your evidence base
    Gather insights from all relevant sources ‚Äî Process Insights, Process Intelligence and Benchmarking systems
  2. Centralize insights in the system
    SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager provides one place where insights are stored, organized, and linked to transformation work.
  3. Link insights to initiatives
    Every well-formed initiative should be backed by explicit insights. This ensures initiatives are based on real need, not assumptions.
  4. Feed insights into continuous improvement
    After implementation, new insights should inform adjustments, refinements, or creation of new initiatives.

What SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager Helps Avoid

  • Initiatives chosen by opinion instead of evidence
    Insights make the prioritization process fact-based and transparent.
  • Overlooking high-value opportunities
    Benchmarking and analytics make performance gaps visible.
  • Losing knowledge during handovers
    Centralized insights preserve organizational memory.
  • Lack of outcome measurement
    Insights tie improvements to measurable changes in KPIs.
  • Fragmented understanding of process behavior
    The platform aggregates data from multiple sources into one coherent view.

Why Insights Matter

Insights reveal where performance deviates, where value is trapped, and where the organization should focus its efforts.
SAP Signavio Process Transformation Manager turns raw analysis into structured, actionable knowledge ‚Äî linking it directly to objectives and initiatives so decisions are grounded in reality, not intuition.

With insights, organizations shift from reactive problem-solving to proactive transformation steering.

entry.title: Adapting the Transition to SAP Cloud ALM Roadmap for Different Project Sizes
entry.content:
Not every customer journey looks the same, even more so when it comes to SAP Cloud ALM. Some are small, starting with one functionality. Others are bigger, transitioning the entire landscape from Solution Manager. There are also the ones that are huge and multi-layered, combining different projects (Operations, Implementation, Transition) and SAP cloud solutions (i.e., SAP Cloud ALM and S/4 HANA). 

No matter the scope or the size of the project you are implementing, the SAP Activate Transition to Cloud ALM roadmap is ready to adapt and help you coordinate the effort needed and the different sequence to be followed. In this blog post, I intend to share some tricks to help you manage and adapt your project without forgetting some important tasks along the way. 

The first thing you need to know is that the Road Map Viewer offers you the option of filtering your roadmaps‚Äô deliverables and tasks accordingly to Phases, Workstreams, Product, Tags (see more on the Important aspects on SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM blog post), and Roles. This may reflect an overall view of what your activities would look like during the project, or help you work on a need-to-know basis. 

When it comes to the visibility of the project in SAP Cloud ALM, you will also have the option of assigning the different tasks to your team members and marking as ‚ÄòNot relevant‚Äô the ones you will not be executing. This means you will be able to adjust the tasks the roadmap is offering you to your needs based on the size and scope of your project. It will also simplify your view on the Guided Implementation functionality in SAP Cloud ALM (see more on Optimize SAP Implementation with SAP Activate Methodology and Guided Implementation in Cloud ALM). 

Regardless of the project size, the Project Management deliverables and tasks are key to help you define your scope and strategy, plan and execute your project. They will also help you analyze the completion of the activities essential for each phase of the project within the Phase Closure and Sign-Off deliverable by executing the Quality Gates. 

For small projects, your focus will be on organizing them well and executing them efficiently and quickly. Therefore, we emphasize the importance of the following four tasks: Define Implementation Strategy, Create a Document Repository for the Implementation Project Team, Direct and Manage Project Execution and Confirm Backlog. These tasks will help you define a clear and strong scope and strategy, execute them effectively and maintain the stakeholders engaged and accountable during the transition. 

When implementing larger projects, besides these tasks, we also recommend you focus on the tasks Set Up Project Team Logistics and Infrastructure and Create Project Schedule and Budget right at the beginning of the project to keep your team on time and on budget, as well as to offer all the needed resources along the way. Besides that, the deliverables Execution and Monitoring of Project are available at the beginning of the Explore, Realize and Deploy phases, which will help you organize and monitor your progress as well as mitigate risks and address issues earlier, and the deliverable Sprint Planning and Execution, which is available in the Realize phase, will help you plan your sprints and iterations. 

While planning your transition either through SAP Cloud ALM for Implementation, SAP Cloud ALM for Operations or both, you may have different journeys, but know that the SAP Activate for Transition to SAP Cloud ALM roadmap will be here to help you adjust and even scale. With the right adjustments, this roadmap becomes more than a methodology ‚Äì it is your personalized path to a confident and successful transition.

entry.title: Re: Is Integration Architecture EA discipline‚Äì or how do we see it?
entry.content:
Hi @wek. 

Thanks for sharing your feedback and let me try to provide some more clarity on some points I made.

  • On TOGAF artifacts - neither SAP EAF (as a framework) not SAP LeanIX (as a tool) are really 1 to 1 with TOGAF. Let's just take an example of ADF - we may say SAP EAF is leveraging on ADF phases, but its just not there. Also, no such a thing as artifacts specific for each ADF phase in SAP LeanIX, although many SAP LeanIX artifacts can be used for EA work should we "tailor" a bit TOGAF...
  • If I talk on "strictly" TOGAF artifacts, my experience would take me to Sparx EA (as a tool), or ArchiMate (for build-by-myself).
  • But none of this matters, as I am not "ridged" TOGAF follower - its been a while since I've started following more Lean EA approach - i.e. AppHaus etc.
  • SAP EAF is great - because it takes a lot from TOGAF, but it also takes a lot of "lean" from SAP AppHaus. Also, SAP LeanIX is a great EAM product - and I like  (among other things) because its an EAM tool on its own.

I am not sharing any criticism to SAP LeanIX - on a contrarily; I am sharing some facts (or at least my views, from my long-term experience). 

On the integration, indeed this is great article/review from HammadSharif1  (I've kudo it). I've been following ISA-M from the very beginning - but as I do my work with heterogenic landscape (both SAP and non-SAP systems), I was sharing more generalist approach is some of my articles (i.e. Integration Architecture Part 1, Part 2, Part 3 and Part 4; or i.e. EDA and Compossible Business Architecture).  But indeed - great inspiration does come ISA-M and SAP Integration Suite (incl. AEM) in general.

Again, big thanks for sharing your feedback - and I hope I was able to clarify some of my points.

entry.title: Re: Field "XXX" in table /1OM/ODM_OEIT_STR_300 is specifi...
entry.content:
Here are a few things you can try:

  1. Run DDIC Consistency Check
    Go to:
    SE14 ‚Üí Utilities ‚Üí Database Object ‚Üí Check
    This sometimes highlights the exact inconsistency inside the structure.

  2. Clear DDIC Buffers
    Use transaction:
    /$SYNC or /nbuf
    Then try activating the structure again in SE11.

  3. Activate Parent Objects
    Activate the higher-level objects where this structure is used (tables, includes).
    Sometimes the inconsistency lies in the parent and not the structure itself.

  4. Try ‚ÄúWhere-Used‚Äù Cleanup
    Use SE11 ‚Üí ‚ÄúWhere-used list‚Äù and check if any dependent include/structure still holds the old field definitions.
    Open them and activate manually.

  5. Regenerate Using SE80 ‚Üí Utilities ‚Üí Regenerate Object List
    This triggers a deeper activation and sometimes resolves the ‚Äúpartly active‚Äù status.

  6. SAP Note 1624942
    This Note usually works only when the structure is locked in an inconsistent state.
    If Z_UNLOCK_R3TR_TABLE didn‚Äôt help, then the issue is not a lock but a DDIC version mismatch.

  7. Transport Level Check
    If this happened after an update/transport, check STMS ‚Üí Import History ‚Üí Logs.
    You might see warnings related to this structure.

  8. If everything fails
    Sometimes only this works:

    • Temporarily rename the duplicate fields

    • Activate

    • Then rename them back
      This forces the system to rebuild the structure internally.

If you can share which exact fields are duplicated, it might help narrow down if it‚Äôs due to an include or an enhancement.

entry.title: Re: U.S SECURE 2.0 Act - Section 603
entry.content:
@Suneetha,  

pre-tax contribution is also checked by 402g limit. So, if you have put the limit in 'total max.' in V_74FH_C, when employee reaches the limit of 23500, catch-up contribution will be pre-tax. 

However, if you put 23500 in Max pre-tax, there seems no way to control the post-tax contribution. 

With 'ROLL', ROTH catch-up doesn't come out for lower income employee when he contributes both pre-tax and ROTH. However, I may need to re-test this scenario with the max pre-tax 23500 to see if this would make a difference. 

Euna

entry.title: Re: Build 8228/8229 Enhancements To Unload/Reload DB Lowe...
entry.content:
There is nothing in those bug releases that would affect the size of a rebuilt database.  

The reduction is size from a rebuild is going to depend on two key aspect - one, the page utilization, and two the number of free pages.  Unfortunately, both metrics are impacted when deletes occur so are not reliable in determining if there were unwanted deletes.  You could translate the transaction log(s) and verify that only the desired deletes were performed as part of the maintenance.

entry.title: Re: Difference between PSM (Public Sector Management) and...
entry.content:
Dear @RP1,

  1. ‚ÄûStandard‚Äù Public Cloud:
  • Use the suffix apps, for example:
    • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules ‚Äì Asset Postings
    • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules ‚Äì Service Documents
    • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules ‚Äì Group Journal Entries
  • SAP Help page: Manage Substitution/Validation Rules describes these contexts and explains that you define rules per business context

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/8837a41d09744bf7963720c41c9f5b83.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/e6175604fc874bfe84aa14d2f9ae1fbd/5c8c2825535f4e3aa9b7f716a0085221.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F4406')/S35

Public Sector Management (PSM):

  • Use Manage Substitution and Validation for Public Sector (F7603)
  • It is listed in the Public Sector Management help node together with Rules for Substitution and Validation in PSM

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F7603')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/273eac91cdab45c1ad2b11839cfd4f35.html

SAP Note 3583820: ‚ÄúApp Manage Substitution and Validation Rules cannot be open‚Äù:

    • Says that the generic app Manage Substitution and Validation Rules (F4406) without suffix is not the correct one to use
    • Recommends using the app with suffix: Manage Substitution/Validation Rules Journal Entries
    • States that the generic app is planned to be removed in CE2508

More details below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3583820

 

  1. Business contexts:

Standard rules:

  • Documented in Rules for Substitution/Validation help topic
  • Lists contexts like:
    • Journal Entry Business
    • Group Reporting
    • GR Journal
    • other financial and logistics contexts

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/8837a41d09744bf7963720c41c9f5b83.html

PSM:

  • Documented separately in Rules for Substitution and Validation in PSM
  • This page and the PSM node list PSM-specific contexts, for example:
    • Integration with Contract Accounting (FI-CA) and rule-based distributions
    • PSM-specific account assignment flows (public sector budgeting, etc.)
    • Links to applications like Rule-Based Account Assignment Distribution and PSM-relevant Asset Accounting scenarios

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/50c85005148941e1a3e6ebe13b4c9f7f.html

  1. Industry / scope dependency:

Standard app:

  • Manage Substitution/Validation Rules help is under Finance and is available in any Public Cloud system with the relevant Finance scope

PSM app:

  • Public Sector Management (PSM) is an industry solution
  • Public documentation for Public Cloud states that PSM features for budgeting, funding and grants are part of a public-sector-specific solution that must be activated as an industry scope

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/39258e361aa8474a89da8f57fc9fd3a4.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Difference between PSM (Public Sector Management) and...
entry.content:
Dear @RP1,

  1. Same rules framework / component
  2. Same rule model
    • Business context
    • Event (for example ‚ÄúBefore save‚Äù, ‚ÄúAfter check‚Äù)
    • Rule type (Validation / Substitution)
    • Precondition ->Action / Message
  3. Same developer extensibility
    • For custom logic
    • For custom function

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/cf92618cf8f849999fc08a03dc53c1a5.html

The engine is the same, the Public Sector variant is not a separate technical framework, it‚Äôs the same rules framework with different business contexts and fields like I wrote in first answer.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Achieving Best-in-Class Invoice Exception KPIs in SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing
entry.content:
One of the clearest indicators of efficiency in an AP organization is the percentage of invoices that can be processed without an exception. Best-in-class performers consistently achieve 85‚Äì90% (or higher) invoice-throughput with zero exceptions. Many SAP Ariba customers operate far below that‚Äîoften without realizing how much time, cost, and user frustration gets tied up in exception handling.

As part of the SAP Ariba Solution Value Advisory team, we work with customers every day to improve adoption and unlock measurable business value. And one consistent theme we see?
Within SAP Ariba Buying & Invoicing or SAP Ariba Invoice Management,  when the ‚Äúinvoices without exceptions‚Äù KPI is low, it‚Äôs usually a sign that key reporting insights or powerful configuration options aren‚Äôt being fully leveraged. Many customers set these tolerances and exception rules at their go-live and never revisit them‚Äîeven as their supplier base, purchasing patterns, and business priorities evolve. The good news is that by analyzing the right reports and adjusting targeted configuration settings, this KPI can be improved quickly and sustainably.

Let‚Äôs walk through why this matters, what you should measure, and how to improve it using SAP Ariba best practices.

Why This KPI Matters

Improving your exception-free invoice rate isn‚Äôt just about efficiency‚Äîit directly impacts:

1. Faster Invoice Cycle Times

Fewer exceptions mean fewer delays. Suppliers get paid quicker. AP teams get out of firefighting mode.

2. Stronger Supplier Relationships

Consistent processing builds trust, predictability, and reduces the back-and-forth inquiries.

3. Lower Operating Cost

Exception handling is expensive. Every unnecessary rework loop adds labor hours.

4. Better User Experience

Buyers, receivers, and AP processors spend less time resolving issues and more time on strategic work.

5. Clean Data Feeding Analytics & Automation

A cleaner invoice process unlocks more opportunities for automation, validations, and future optimization.

Step 1: Measure What‚Äôs Really Happening

Before solving problems, you need a clear look at them.

I always recommend customers start by running the following in SAP Ariba:

Exception Reports by:

  • Exception type

  • Supplier

  • Commodity

This gives a precise view of where your exceptions are coming from. Often, 80% of issues originate from 10‚Äì15 suppliers or a handful of commodities.

This becomes your roadmap.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Supplier

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Supplier

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each supplier.

How to create a custom SAP Ariba Analytical Report for Invoice Exception by Commodity

Create an Analytical Report

Name it "Invoice Exceptions by Commodity

1.  Choose "Invoice Exceptions" as the Main Fact

2. Choose "Invoice" as the Second Fact

3. Choose the Measure "Invoice with Exception Count"

on the 2nd page of the report creation

4. Choose "Commodity L2" (Choose the level you desire) from the Invoice Exception Fact as a Row Field

5.  Choose "Invoice ID" from the Invoice Exception Fact and "ERP Supplier" from the Invoice Fact as Data Fields

Run the report

6.  Expand "[Invoice Exceptions] Invoice Exception Type" and select an invoice exception to see how many was raised for each Commodity L2.

Interpret the Results and Identify Where to Act

Once you‚Äôve run your exception reports by supplier and commodity, the real value comes from how you use the findings. This is where customers often unlock quick wins.

Start by reviewing:

  • Which suppliers generate the highest number of exceptions

  • Which commodities consistently trigger the same exception types

  • Patterns across PO types or line items

In most organizations, a small group of suppliers or categories is responsible for the majority of exceptions. This makes your next steps much more focused and targeted.

Use the Data to Drive Configuration Improvements

If you see that receiving exceptions are concentrated around certain suppliers or commodities, this is a strong indicator that your receiving process may not fit how those suppliers operate. For example, many high-volume, fast-shipping suppliers (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, IT accessories, etc.) ship and invoice so quickly that end users rarely have time to receive the items manually.

This is exactly where SAP Ariba‚Äôs configuration options can help.

Step 2: Strategy & Configuration Options to Improve Your KPI

Below are the most effective levers that customers have used to reduce invoice exceptions and move toward best-in-class performance.

1. Use Auto-Receiving for High-Velocity, Low-Risk Suppliers

If you see a high volume of receiving exceptions for certain suppliers‚Äîespecially those who ship quickly (office supplies, MRO, janitorial, safety, IT peripherals)‚Äîauto-receiving can significantly improve your throughput.

Why this works

Many of these suppliers ship and invoice same-day. That leaves almost no time for end users to receive goods manually. Auto-receipt ensures:

  • Fewer receiving exceptions

  • Faster invoice processing

  • Less burden on casual users

How to configure

Auto-receiving can be based on:

  • Supplier & Supplier Part Number or by only Supplier 

  • Commodity

2. Review and Adjust Tax Exception Tolerances

Tax exceptions are common, especially in jurisdictions where suppliers calculate tax differently or round amounts differently.

How to improve

  • Review your current tax variance tolerances

  • Identify suppliers consistently triggering small variances

  • Adjust tolerances to realistic levels aligned with procurement policy

This can be strategically relaxed only where justified‚Äînot globally.

3. Evaluate Shipping Cost Tolerances

Shipping exceptions often occur when:

  • The supplier charges small shipping amounts not included on the PO 

  • When outside a stated percentage tolerance of the invoice amount

Options

  • Set reasonable shipping % tolerances

  • Use flat-rate dollar tolerances for specific suppliers

  • Update templates for certain commodities where shipping is always variable

4. Leverage Invoice Exception Overrides (By Supplier or Commodity)

This is one of the most under-used but highly effective tools SAP Ariba customers have.

What They Are

Invoice exception overrides allow you to set:

  • Different tolerance percentages

  • Different dollar limits

For specific suppliers, commodity codes, or currency.

Why It Matters

Most exceptions are not systemic‚Äîthey are concentrated. Overrides let you tune the system where the problem exists, without weakening global controls.

Examples

  • For a trusted supplier with a predictable pattern, allow a slightly higher price variance.

  • For a commodity where tax always fluctuates (e.g., services), apply more flexible thresholds.

  • Ensure to adjust amount tolerances per currency

5. Work With Suppliers When Exceptions Follow a Pattern

Sometimes exceptions are not a configuration issue, but a supplier process issue.

Consider supplier-facing improvements such as:

  • Reinforcing PO-Flip usage

  • Ensuring suppliers invoice based on PO quantities only

  • Updating supplier enablement documentation

  • Aligning catalog pricing with contracts

  • Negotiating tax and shipping behavior

Remember‚Äîsuppliers want faster invoice processing too.

Step 3: Communicate Improvements and Track Progress

Once you‚Äôve implemented changes, measure the impact:

  • Exception rate by supplier month-over-month

  • Top 10 exception drivers (before vs. after)

  • Auto-receive success rates

  • Percentage reduction in tax/shipping exceptions

Customers who follow this approach typically see:

  • 20‚Äì40% reduction in exceptions within 90 days

  • Major improvements in user satisfaction

  • A measurable boost in straight-through invoice processing

Final Thoughts

Improving your ‚Äúinvoices without exceptions‚Äù KPI is not about relaxing controls‚Äîit‚Äôs about applying the right controls in the right places. The strategies in this article come directly from working with many SAP Ariba customers, across industries, who have successfully increased adoption and reduced AP workload through targeted process and configuration optimization.

If your KPI is below best-in-class, use this as a starting point. A few focused adjustments can create a major lift in processing speed, supplier satisfaction, and AP efficiency.

entry.title: Issue Accessing Withholding Tax Configuration Apps in S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì Missing Business Catalogs
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We are currently validating the configuration of withholding tax in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and during the tax calculation review we identified that the system is returning incorrect values compared to the expected configuration.

When verifying the setup, we found that two key configuration points are inaccessible due to missing system authorizations. According to the official SAP documentation, these configuration steps require access through specific Business Catalogs; however, when searching for them within our system, no results are returned, preventing us from completing the validation.

The applications we need access to are:

  • Define Withholding Tax Keys Specific to the Country/Region (ID: 106626)

  • Assign Withholding Tax Keys to Withholding Tax Codes (ID: 105911)

Additionally, we referenced SAP documentation where these Business Catalogs appear as configuration elements for countries such as Spain and Indonesia, but they do not seem to be available in our tenant.

Given this situation, we are considering raising a support case under the B-Component XX-CBC-CE-CON (CBC ‚Äì Configuration Environment). Before doing so, I would like to confirm with the community:

Questions

  1. Are these configuration applications deprecated, country-specific, or currently restricted in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2508)?

  2. Is there an updated Business Catalog or role required to enable access to these specific withholding tax configuration steps?

  3. Has anyone experienced the same issue where the Business Catalogs referenced in SAP documentation are not available in the system?

  4. Should this indeed be escalated through a CBC support case, or is there an alternative resolution (e.g., different catalog, role collection, or change in country template availability)?

I have attached evidence showing that the Business Catalogs related to these apps appear in SAP documentation but are not available in our system.

Thank you in advance for your guidance and any insights you can share.

entry.title: Onboarding 2.0 IAS/IPS provisioning: Hire gets two provisioning emails if rehire
entry.content:
Hello,

We have completed our IAS/IPS Tenant Migration and activated the ‚Äòreal-time sync‚Äô functionality for our Onboarding 2.0 application. In addition, we have the switch ‚ÄúRetain Onboarding Username for Rehire on Old Employment‚Äù active in Onboarding General Settings.

Prior to the IAS/IPS Tenant migration and the real-time sync, the following process took place:

  1. The Review New Hire Data step is completed by HR. IPS Read Job creates Onboarding credentials and provisioning email is sent from IAS.
  2. Hire enters SSN/DOB into Onboarding. This triggers the Rehire Validation check assuming the hire is a rehire.
  3. HR completes the Rehire Validation check and selects ‚ÄúRehire with Old Employment‚Äù.
  4. Existing IAS username and password is retained by the hire. They do not get a second email from IAS. A rehire email is sent from Email Services. If they are still logged into ONB 2.0, they can even refresh their browser to continue Onboarding.
  5. Rehire completes their Onboarding tasks with their existing IAS credentials.

Now, with the IAS/IPS tenant migration and the real-time sync, below the new process:

  1. Steps 1-3 above are the same.
  2. Hire now gets a second Hire/Welcome email from IAS. They are required to re-authenticate and specify a new password. The old password no longer works.
  3. Rehire completes their Onboarding tasks with their new IAS credentials.

Ideally, we‚Äôd love the process to retain the Onboardee‚Äôs prior IAS credentials, even with the real-time sync and the tenant migration in place. Has anyone solved this? 

Regards,

Jay Crowley

entry.title: Authorization management with OpenSearch's Document Level Security - SAP Cloud Logging
entry.content:
The shift to SAP Cloud Logging service introduces several improvements over its predecessor, the SAP Application Logging service (Cloud Foundry). One major benefit is the ability to use a single Cloud Logging instance across multiple CF spaces and even multiple CF orgs/subaccounts. (For more details, see the blog post Instance Sharing ‚Äì SAP Cloud Logging.)

However, the authorization model is different fromSAP Application Logging service (Cloud Foundry). Application Logging supported only read-only access and implicitly reused CF space permissions.  

Cloud Logging, on the other hand:

  • Supports read/write use cases
  • Allows creating custom content
  • Enables centralization and sharing

In order to support such extended scenarios, Cloud Logging integrates with SAP Cloud Identity Services - Identity Authentication (IAS) for flexible authentication and authorization.

This document guides on how to leverage Document Level Security (DLS) in OpenSearch Roles (+) IAS Groups to setup flexible authorization. It explains using few common use cases including the prominent one - replicating the familiar space-level separation, based on user's CF Space assignment, within a unified logging instance.

  • OpenSearch Security Model Overview
  • Index-Level vs. Document-Level Security
  • The DLS Strategy: Restricting Views by Space ID
  • Use Case 1: Fixed Authorization for Specific Spaces (Space-A and Space-B)
  • Step 1:Create IAS Groups (Backend Roles)
  • Step 2: Define OpenSearch Roles
  • Step 3: Map Backend Roles to OpenSearch Roles
  • Use Case 2: Multi-Space Access for Shared Teams (e.g., Finance)
  • Use Case 3: Using Other Fields
  • Use Case 4: Parameter Substitution for Dynamic Authorization
  • High-Level Overview: IAS Group Mapping and Space-Based Access Control in OpenSearch
  • Important Considerations (DLS Best Practices)
  • 1. Avoid Wildcard Index Match (*) :
  • 2. DLS and Write Permissions:
  • 3. Admin Roles Combined with DLS Roles
  • 4. DLS Query Syntax: Precision is Key

OpenSearch Security Model Overview

OpenSearch's security model provides the foundation for integrating with external Identity Providers (IdPs) like SAP IAS:

ComponentDefinitionIntegration
UsersIndividual accounts accessing OpenSearch.Authenticated via SAP IAS.
OpenSearch Roles

Collections of permissions (read, write, manage) and security filters (DLS).

Cloud Logging ships with default roles, and customers may create additional ones.

The mechanism for authorization.
Backend RolesGroups or roles assigned to the user within the SAML/OIDC Identity Provider ‚Äî in this case SAP IAS Group names.The bridge between SAP IAS and OpenSearch Roles.
Roles MappingThe link that connects IAS groups (backend roles) to OpenSearch roles. How users inherit OpenSearch permissions.

Note: 

Since IAS groups are customer-defined, Cloud Logging can only pre-map the IAS group that should serve as instance admin to OpenSearch‚Äôs all_access role. All other mappings must be configured by the customer.

Index-Level vs. Document-Level Security

  • Index-Level Security controls which indices a user can access.

  • Document-Level Security (DLS) controls which documents inside an index a user can access.

To restrict users to logs from a specific CF space, you apply DLS.

The DLS Strategy: Restricting Views by Space ID

To achieve security separation, every log document must contain a field that identifies its CF source. We assume this field is named space_name (mapped as space_name.keyword in OpenSearch).

DLS works by appending a mandatory filter‚Äîan OpenSearch Query DSL statement‚Äîto every search request made by a user assigned to the role. This filter ensures the user only retrieves documents where the space_name.keyword matches their authorized space(s).

Use Case 1: Fixed Authorization for Specific Spaces (Space-A and Space-B)

When you have a small number of distinct spaces (e.g., space-A and space-B), and each requires a dedicated authorization group, you create a static OpenSearch Role for each.

Step 1: Create IAS Groups (Backend Roles)

  • space-A-read-only
  • space-B-read-only

Step 2: Define OpenSearch Roles

We will define two roles, each allowing read-only access to log indices but restricted by DLS.

A. Role for Space-A (role-space-A-read-only)

  1. Navigate to OpenSearch Dashboards > Security > Roles.

  2. Clone the default readall role and name it role-space-A-read-only.
  3. Cluster permissions: cluster_composite_ops_ro
  4. Index Permissions:

    • Index Pattern: logs-*(Specify a pattern like this instead of only specifying an asterisk * to avoid applying DLS to system indices).

    • Index Permissions: Select read
    • Document Level Security: Enter the DLS query for the specific space: 
{
  "term": {
    "space_name.keyword": "space-A"
  }
}‚Äã

B. Role for Space-B (role-space-B-read-only)

Repeat the above steps for role-space-B-read-only, changing the value in the DLS query to "space-B".

Step 3: Map Backend Roles to OpenSearch Roles

This step links the SAP IAS groups to the newly created security filters.

  1. Navigate to OpenSearch Dashboards > Security > Roles.

  2. Select role-space-A-read-only.

  3. Click the Mapped Users tab and then Manage Mapping.

  4. Under Backend roles, add the SAP IAS group name: space-A-read-only.

Repeat this process for role-space-B-read-only, mapping it to the space-B-read-only backend role.

Crucial Note on Dashboards Access: You must also map these new Backend Roles (space-A-read-only, space-B-read-only)to the OpenSearch role global_tenant_read_access to allow users to see and use shared dashboards and visualizations.

Use Case 2: Multi-Space Access for Shared Teams (e.g., Finance)

If you need to define a single role for a department (e.g., Finance) that needs access to a specific list of CF spaces (space-A, space-C, space-D), you can use terms query to add multiple values.

UI Steps for a finance_spaces_read_only Role:

  1. Clone the default OpenSearch Role readall and name it finance_spaces_read_only.

  2. Set the Index Pattern and Permissions as explained in Use Case 1.
  3. Document Level Security: Enter the terms query to include all required spaces: 
{
  "terms": {
    "space_name.keyword": [
      "space-A",
      "space-C",
      "space-D"
    ]
  }
}

Map this role to the relevant SAP IAS group (e.g., finance_spaces_read_only) as explained in Use Case 1.

Use Case 3: Using Other Fields

The same DLS concepts apply to:

  • organization_id

  • organization_name
  • app_name

You can restrict access on any well-defined keyword field stored in your logs. 

Use Case 4: Parameter Substitution for Dynamic Authorization

For maximum scalability, instead of creating one OpenSearch role per space, you can create a single role that dynamically substitutes the user‚Äôs backend roles into the DLS query.

This works when IAS group names match the field values ‚Äî for example:

  • finance_space_prod
  • finance_space_staging
  • finance_space_dev

In OpenSearch, the variable ${user.roles} references the list of backend roles (IAS groups) assigned to the user.

UI Steps for a Dynamic Role:

  1. Create a single OpenSearch Role (e.g., dynamic_space_member).

  2. Set the Index Pattern and Permissions as before.

  3. Document Level Security: Use the ${user.roles} substitution variable in a terms query: 

{
  "terms": {
    "space_name.keyword": [ ${user.roles} ]
  }
}

Result: When a user logs in, if they are assigned to the IAS groups finance_space_staging and finance_space_dev, the DLS query automatically evaluated to "terms": { "space_name.keyword": ["finance_space_staging", "finance_space_dev"] }. The user is only shown logs where space_name exactly matches one of their assigned IAS groups.

Map this role to a general backend role pattern (e.g., finance_space*) to cover all relevant IAS groups.

 

High-Level Overview: IAS Group Mapping and Space-Based Access Control in OpenSearch

Important Considerations (DLS Best Practices)

1. Avoid Wildcard Index Match (*) :

Avoid using a plain wildcard (*) for index patterns in your DLS roles. This includes system indices (like .kibana), which can break Dashboards functionality when DLS is applied. Always use a targeted pattern like logs-*, otel-*

2. DLS and Write Permissions:

A user with a DLS-configured role must not be granted write permissions. If they index a document they cannot retrieve (due to DLS filtering), it creates invisible data they cannot manage. DLS is intended for read-only access control.

3. Admin Roles Combined with DLS Roles

When a user with multiple roles (usually Admins) logs in, OpenSearch combines DLS rules from multiple roles using a logical OR. However if a restricted role with DLS is combined with a role with empty DLS, the unrestricted role will not override the DLS rule, and access remains restricted according to role with DLS.

This is the secure, expected behaviour:

  • Admin role: empty DLS

  • Restricted role: with a restricted DLS
  • Combined: restricted role takes precedence (since empty DLS does NOT override a restrictive one)

Background: The admin role has an "empty" DLS configuration which by default does not override a restrictive one. In Cloud Logging, plugins.security.dfm_empty_overrides_all is disabled, so empty DLS doesn‚Äôt override.

Workaround to Give Admins Full Access

  1. Duplicate the all_access role ‚Üí all_access_advanced

  2. Change index pattern: from * to a targeted pattern like logs-*
  3. Add a match-all DLS:  {"match_all":{}}
  4. Ensure admin backend role is mapped to this new role.

4. DLS Query Syntax: Precision is Key

For security and performance, use DLS filters with term query on a .keyword field.

# Option 1: works but has limitations

{ 
 "bool": { 
   "must": { 
     "match": { 
       "space_name.keyword": "space-name-A" 
     } 
   } 
 } 
} 

vs. 

# Option 2: preferred
{ 
‚ÄØ "term": { 
‚ÄØ‚ÄØ‚ÄØ "space_name.keyword": "space-name-A" 
‚ÄØ } 
}
  • Although match  (combined with .keyword) works, it triggers analyzers and scoring logic.
  • Furthermore, it is not guaranteed to remain exact under future mapping or analyzer changes which are risky when used for authorization.
  • term is faster, safer, and the only deterministic option for Lucene-level DLS.
Term Look up: 

If you use term lookup queries (not the simple Term query) or other constructs, DLS falls back to Filter-level DLS instead of the most efficient Lucene-level DLS which might have to be considered when filtering on large data sets. (read more on DLS evaluation modes).

üîö

Official OpenSearch DLS documentation: https://docs.opensearch.org/2.19/security/access-control/document-level-security/

entry.title: Do you really need to re-invent the wheel to start posting on SAP Community? ü§î
entry.content:
A few years ago I used to feel intimidated by other colleagues posting on the SAP Community and on LinkedIn -most of them are now my friends-, Reading their headlines and posts and thinking "How do these people know that much about SAP, ABAP, etcetera?" and "Where do these people find time to post?". ü§î

The truth is that I was so disconnected from the SAP Community that almost everything seemed to me new and "out of my league", even more considering that in those days I was stuck in the "old and reliable"  ECC projects. Not by choice of course! ü§≠

The things started to change a little when I got my first real project opportunity to work on an S/4HANA project, but it wasn't enough yet, I was still feeling left behind. So, I started little by little to pay more attention to the SAP Community and SAP related content on LinkedIn and other SAP official social media accounts, watching the Developer News while Googling what they were talking about. 

That made me realize two things:

  1. Yeah, these people is truly smart!
  2. I could be part of them too! (So you can too!).

I started on LinkedIn with "silly posts" about how SAP was related to companies, series, movies and bands I liked. Then going a little technical talking about what I thought it was "common knowledge" like SE16H, SM20, etcetera. I realized one more thing, that knowledge wasn't as common as I thought... Which takes us here, do we really need to be an eminence or re-invent the wheel to start posting on SAP Community? The short answer is NO!

Paraphrasing Chef Gusteau in Ratatouille "Anybody can write/post". So, the next time you get the impostor syndrome and starting to feel like George McFly ("What if they told me I was no good?") just remember my story and think: "If that average and random ABAPer made it, I can make it too!". 

Believe me, there is a lot of fun in posting, sharing knowledge and engaging with the SAP Community -in all platforms and social media networks-. I hope this post accomplish its mission of encouraging you to start posting now. 

PS: If you start posting, please send me a message, I'd love to be one of the first reading you!

entry.title: Re: P&L must balance after corr in GR
entry.content:
Good day @florading 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Changing FS Item Hierarchy, Reporting Items and Reporting Rules, Calculate Net Income, How to Run Calculate Net Income, Balance Validation.        

The analysis of the screenshots you provided highlights reasons why you get the error despite your system haven created the FS item 799000. Here is what I noticed:

  • First, the validation rule SE00008 fails because you NI+ Clearing accounts does not equal the target FS item balance=0.
  • So, your system basically reads your clearing account √† 1,000 CNY, while FS Item 799000 √† 0 CNY. Which means your NI+ clearing is not equal to 0 and therefore your revenue/expense is not fully rolled into your Net Income.
  • Even though the system generated 799000, the FS items mapping is still incomplete.

To summarise, the cause of the error is because NI (799000) does not include the clearing account (585000) posting because your FS Item mapping might be missing or incorrect. What this means is that Group Reporting will only derive NI only after you run FS hierarchy, Net Income Calculation and Release UJ.

I suggest you a look at the following in your system:

  • Check that your FS item hierarchy, ensure 585000 rolls into P&L
  • Run Release UJ, then  calculate Net Income, thereafter  check Currency Translation.
  • Make sure you revalidate the rule and ensure clearing accounts are included in the validation method SE00008

This will ensure NI and clearing will be balanced and thereby ensuring validation is successful.

Let me know if you have further question on the CDS views creation.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: OOALV Implementation of Checkbox Click Event Issue
entry.content:
Problem with Implementing Single Click Event for Checkboxes in OOALV
I've successfully implemented a function where when I check one row, other rows meeting certain conditions are also automatically checked.
However, an issue occurs when there's a large amount of data in the ALV. When I check a row, that specific row appears as unchecked in the display, while all other rows meeting the conditions are properly checked. During debugging, I found that the internal table has been correctly assigned with value 'X', but for some reason, the ALV display shows it as unchecked.
Below is my OOALV code.

CLASS cl_event_receiver DEFINITION.
  PUBLIC SECTION.

    METHODS handle_hotspot_click
      FOR EVENT hotspot_click OF cl_gui_alv_grid
      IMPORTING e_row_id e_column_id.

    METHODS handle_double_click
      FOR EVENT double_click OF cl_gui_alv_grid
      IMPORTING e_row e_column.
ENDCLASS.                    "cl_event_receiver DEFINITION




  METHOD handle_data_changed.
    DATA: lt_mod_cells TYPE lvc_t_modi,
          ls_mod       TYPE lvc_s_modi,
          lv_DZDH      TYPE zmmt006-dzdh,
          lv_lifnr     TYPE ekko-lifnr,
          lv_bukrs     TYPE ekko-bukrs.

    DATA: ls_row    TYPE lvc_s_row,
          ls_col    TYPE lvc_s_col,
          lv_row_id TYPE lvc_index.

    READ TABLE er_data_changed->mt_good_cells INTO ls_mod INDEX 1.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR ls_mod-fieldname <> 'SEL'.
      RETURN. 
    ENDIF.

    CALL METHOD go_alv->get_current_cell
      IMPORTING
        es_row_id = ls_row
        es_col_id = ls_col.
    lv_row_id = ls_row-index.

    READ TABLE gt_alv INTO DATA(ls_alv) INDEX ls_mod-row_id.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      RETURN.
    ELSE.

      lv_lifnr = ls_alv-lifnr.
      lv_bukrs = ls_alv-bukrs.
      lv_dzdh  = ls_alv-dzdh.

      IF p4 = 'X'.
        IF ls_alv-sel IS INITIAL.
          LOOP AT gt_alv ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_alv>)
               WHERE dzdh = lv_DZDH.
            <fs_alv>-sel = 'X'.
          ENDLOOP.
        ELSE.
          LOOP AT gt_alv ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_alv2>)
               WHERE dzdh = lv_DZDH.
            <fs_alv2>-sel = ''.
          ENDLOOP.
        ENDIF.
      ELSE .
        IF ls_alv-sel IS INITIAL.
          LOOP AT gt_alv ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_alv1>)
               WHERE lifnr = lv_lifnr AND bukrs = lv_bukrs.
            <fs_alv1>-sel = 'X'.
          ENDLOOP.
        ELSE.
          LOOP AT gt_alv ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_alv3>)
               WHERE lifnr = lv_lifnr AND bukrs = lv_bukrs.
            <fs_alv3>-sel = ''.
          ENDLOOP.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.

    ENDIF.

    IF go_alv IS BOUND.
      DATA(ls_stable) = VALUE lvc_s_stbl( row = 'X' col = 'X' ).
      go_alv->refresh_table_display( is_stable = ls_stable ).
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.                              "handle_data_changed.
  
  

FORM call_alv_grid.
  CONSTANTS:
    lc_a TYPE c LENGTH 1 VALUE 'A'.

  DATA:
    ls_variant TYPE disvariant,
    ls_layout  TYPE lvc_s_layo,
    lt_exclude TYPE ui_functions.

  PERFORM set_variant_layout CHANGING ls_variant ls_layout.


  IF event_receiver IS INITIAL.
    CREATE OBJECT event_receiver.
  ENDIF.


  SET HANDLER event_receiver->handle_toolbar FOR go_alv.

  IF go_alv IS BOUND.
    CALL METHOD go_alv->set_table_for_first_display
      EXPORTING
        is_variant           = ls_variant 
        is_layout            = ls_layout  
        i_save               = lc_a 
        i_default            = gc_x 
        it_toolbar_excluding = lt_exclude 
      CHANGING
        it_outtab            = gt_alv "gt_table
        it_fieldcatalog      = gt_fieldcat. 
  ENDIF.


  SET HANDLER event_receiver->handle_hotspot_click  FOR go_alv.
  SET HANDLER event_receiver->handle_double_click   FOR go_alv.
  SET HANDLER event_receiver->handle_data_changed FOR go_alv.
  SET HANDLER event_receiver->handle_command FOR go_alv.



  CALL METHOD cl_gui_control=>set_focus
    EXPORTING
      control = go_alv.


  CALL METHOD go_alv->register_edit_event 
    EXPORTING
      i_event_id = cl_gui_alv_grid=>mc_evt_modified. 



  FREE: lt_exclude, gt_fieldcat.

ENDFORM. " CALL_ALV_GRID

entry.title: Error while sending email using custom email template using ABAP program.
entry.content:
I have created an email template using CDS View and calling the email Template using ABAP and using below code to send email where I am getting " No data supplied to the template" error. Here is the Code Dump. Any suggestions?

ABAP Code:

    DATA : email_template_name TYPE smtg_tmpl_id VALUE 'ZZ1_DEMO_TEMP',
           sales_order_id TYPE VBAK-VBELN VALUE '0000000040'.


    DATA(bcs) = cl_bcs=>create_persistent( ).

    DATA(email_api) =  cl_smtg_email_api=>get_instance(
            iv_template_id = email_template_name  ).

	DATA(sales_order_cds_key) =
             VALUE if_smtg_email_template=>ty_gt_data_key(
                  ( name = 'SalesDocument'
                    value = sales_order_id ) ).

    TRY.

        " Integrate E-Mail subject and body with email instance
        email_api->render_bcs(
                  io_bcs = bcs
                 iv_language = 'E'
                  iv_language_default = 'E'
                  it_data_key =  sales_order_cds_key

                 ).


        DATA(email_receipient)  =
                   cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address(
                          'test@email.com' ).

        bcs->add_recipient(
                    EXPORTING i_recipient  = email_receipient    ).

        bcs->send( ) .

        COMMIT WORK .

      CATCH cx_bcs INTO DATA(lx_bcs).
        " Handle the exception, e.g., log or output error message
        out->write( lx_bcs->get_text( ) ).
    ENDTRY.

Code Dump

An exception has occurred in class "CX_SMTG_EMAIL_COMMON". This exception was not caught
in procedure "IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN~MAIN" "(METHOD)" or propagated by a RAISING clause.
Since the caller of the procedure could not have anticipated this
exception, the current program was terminated.
The reason for the exception occurring was:
The reason for the exception is:
No data supplied to render email template "ZZ1_DEMO_TEMP"

 

Information on where terminated

The termination occurred in ABAP program or include "CL_SMTG_EMAIL_RENDERER========CP", in "APPLY". The
main program was "SAPMSSY1".

In the source code, the termination point is in line 55 of include "CL_SMTG_EMAIL_RENDERER========CM001".
include "CL_SMTG_EMAIL_RENDERER========CM001".
The termination is due to exception "CX_SMTG_EMAIL_COMMON" occurring in procedure "IF_OO_ADT_CLASSRUN~MAIN" "(METHOD)",
but not being handled locally there or being declared in the RAISING
clause.
The procedure is in program "ZABAP_TEMP=============CP". Its source code begins in line 1 of
include "ZABAP_TEMP=============CM001".

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP as fundamental part of SAP Business Suite for Industrial Manufacturing (2508 Release)
entry.content:
Introduction

Industrial manufacturing is at a crossroads. The industry faces mounting pressures from global market shifts, technological advancements, and the imperative to operate more sustainably. At the same time, new opportunities are emerging for those ready to embrace change. As the industry evolves, the ability to adapt quickly, innovate continuously, and build resilient operations has become essential. This post explores how SAP Cloud ERP as part of SAP Business Suite is enabling industrial manufacturers navigate this transformation, drawing on the latest insights from our industry update with the 2508 release.

Watch the full recording here: Industrial Manufacturing Industry Update - PET H2 2025

The Evolving Landscape of Industrial Manufacturing

Industrial manufacturing companies are defined by their ability to transform raw materials into finished goods at scale, serving a wide range of markets from household appliances to heavy equipment. Many organizations operate across several industry subsegments, often as a result of mergers and acquisitions, which adds complexity to their operations and increases the demands placed on their ERP systems.

Today‚Äôs manufacturers are not only expected to deliver high-quality products efficiently but also to manage increasingly complex supply chains, comply with evolving regulations, and respond to rapid changes in customer demand. The need for robust, flexible, and integrated business systems has never been greater.

Key Challenges and Industry Trends

Recent industry studies and ongoing engagement with customers have highlighted several persistent challenges. Business growth remains a top priority, with manufacturers seeking to attract new customers and enter new markets. However, legacy systems often lack the capabilities needed to support new business models or the localization required for global expansion. Supply chain resilience is another critical concern. Manufacturers are striving to build closer relationships with suppliers and gain deeper visibility into their supply chains, but many lack the systems to enable real-time insights or to streamline the onboarding of new partners.

Operational efficiency is also under pressure. Companies are looking to maximize the effectiveness of both machines and workforce, often through automation and upskilling. Yet, manual processes and limited visibility into production capacity can hinder progress. Finally, technology adoption remains a challenge. Many manufacturers are still reliant on inflexible legacy systems, with data locked away in silos and not easily accessible for business decision-making. The transition to cloud-based, data-driven operations is essential for unlocking new value and staying competitive with the help of AI.

SAP‚Äôs Approach: Building the Intelligent, Sustainable Enterprise

SAP Cloud ERP is designed to address these challenges head-on. The solution provides a strong foundation for industrial manufacturers, offering pre-configured, ready-to-run, end-to-end scenarios that can be deployed quickly and adapted as business needs evolve. Integration with SAP Business Technology Platform and a broad ecosystem of SAP and Partner solutions ensures that customers can support their unique processes while benefiting from continuous innovation.

A key strength of SAP‚Äôs approach is its support for both headquarter scenarios and subsidiaries through two-tier ERP models. This enables organizations to maintain strict governance and standardization at the corporate level while allowing subsidiaries the flexibility to operate in ways that best suit their local markets or distinct business models.

End-to-End Scenarios for Modern Manufacturing

SAP Cloud ERP supports a wide range of manufacturing archetypes, each tailored to the specific needs of different industry segments. E.g. for component manufacturers, make-to-stock scenarios enable efficient production planning, procurement, and sales from inventory. Machinery manufacturers benefit from assemble-to-order and configure-to-order processes, which provide the flexibility to meet individual customer requirements.

End-to-end scenarios are designed to span the entire industrial manufacturing value chain, from idea to market, source to pay, plan to fulfill, and lead to cash. By connecting every part of the business, manufacturers gain greater visibility, control, and the ability to respond quickly to changing conditions.

Innovations in the SAP Cloud ERP 2508 Release

The latest release of SAP Cloud ERP brings several important enhancements for industrial manufacturers. In production planning and execution, the capacity scheduling board introduces activity coloring, allowing production planners to distinguish between setup, production, and teardown times at a glance. This provides clearer insights into operations and helps optimize resource utilization.

 

Component availability checks have also been added to the capacity scheduling table, enabling planners to verify that all necessary parts are on stock before scheduling production orders, thus reducing the risk of costly delays.

 

AI-Assisted Processing of Incoming Quality Certificates with SAP Document AI automatically processes incoming quality certificate documents. By leveraging SAP Document AI on BTP, the data extraction and automatic attachment of certificates to relevant receipts become a hassle-free reality. This allows to handle certificates more efficiently and helps ensure that nothing is lost or overlooked.

 

In sales management, SAP‚Äôs AI copilot, Joule, can now handle expiring prices, automate renewals, and identify fulfillment issues in sales orders, helping sales teams work more efficiently and proactively. 

  

Advanced Variant Configuration capabilities have also been enhanced. Multi-level bills of materials can now be downloaded for easier comparison, and configurations can be imported from sales documents for reuse, streamlining the process of managing complex product variants.

 

  

Customer Success Stories: Real-World Impact

The value of SAP Cloud ERP is best illustrated through the experiences of leading industrial manufacturers. DINE Inc., a South Korean manufacturer specializing in high-precision machining tools, faced challenges with an outdated ERP system that hindered digital transformation and data reliability. By implementing SAP Cloud ERP, DINE achieved unified accounting management across global operations, standardized workflows, and enhanced data visibility. The results included a doubling of profit and loss analysis accuracy, a 1.5-fold increase in inventory turnover rate, and a 10% reduction in spare parts inventory value.

Tetra Pak eBeam Systems AG, headquartered in Switzerland, sought to modernize operations after being acquired by Tetra Pak in 2020. By adopting SAP Cloud ERP and leveraging the SAP Activate methodology, the company reduced upgrade preparation time from eight hours to two, improved user experience, and enabled IT resources to focus on strategic initiatives.

Other customers, such as Acceleron and Ferrotec, have also realized significant benefits. Acceleron consolidated more than 20 ERP systems into a single global business foundation in the cloud, enabling unified processes across 40 countries. Ferrotec Manufacturing Malaysia Sdn. Bhd. improved finance team productivity by 40%, procurement efficiency by 90%, and reduced supply chain costs by half.

Key Takeaways for Industrial Manufacturers

The journey to becoming an agile, intelligent, and sustainable enterprise is both challenging and rewarding. SAP Cloud ERP serves as a catalyst for transformation, enabling manufacturers to adapt quickly, streamline operations, and unlock new business models. Artificial intelligence and automation are driving efficiency and resilience, reducing manual effort and empowering teams to make better decisions. Integrated, end-to-end processes ensure that every part of the business is connected, delivering greater visibility and control.

Perhaps most importantly, the experiences of leading manufacturers demonstrate real world impact and measurable value. From improved operational efficiency to enhanced compliance and accelerated growth, SAP Cloud ERP is helping organizations to future-proof their businesses for continuous growth and thrive in a rapidly changing world.

Conclusion

Industrial manufacturing is evolving at an unprecedented pace. The path to sustainable growth and long-term success lies in embracing digital transformation and building resilient, data-driven operations. SAP Cloud ERP and the entire SAP Business Suite continues to evolve with innovations which empowers manufacturers to meet today‚Äôs challenges and seize tomorrow‚Äôs opportunities. By working together with SAP, we can deliver exceptional value and shape the future of industrial manufacturing.

For more information on how SAP can support your transformation journey, we invite you to connect with our team or visit our website: Industrial Manufacturing Industry Software | SAP

Want to know more?

Bert Schulze shared the Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, my colleague Markus Oertelt shared what‚Äôs new in Manufacturing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and my colleague Leonie Peterka has written the Quality Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 blog post. Here you will find even more innovations for industrial manufacturers and other businesses.

Hello @AikoFC 

Could you please have a look on the following guidance mentioned in SAP Help Portal?

MM - Purchase order (only open PO)
=>
Mapping Instructions
The Delivery Date field on the Item Data sheet is not relevant for products with the type Service and item category Enhanced Limits. In this situation, fill in the Start Date for Period of Performance, End Date for Period of Performance, and Product Type Group (with the value 2 = service for type Service) fields. Otherwise, the Delivery Date is filled with the system date.

Best regards,
Irene

entry.content:
Êú¨ÊñáÂÜÖÂÆπÁøªËØëHow to find CDS views in S/4HANA Public Cloud Edit... - SAP Community

 

Â¶ÇÊûúÊÇ®ÂØπBTPÊÑüÂÖ¥Ë∂£ÔºåBTP‰∏™‰∫∫Á≤æÈÄâÂÜÖÂÆπÁõÆÂΩï | SAP Blogs ÂèØËÉΩÊúâÊõ¥Â§ö‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÂÜÖÂÆπ

 

ÁÆÄË¶ÅÊ¶ÇËø∞

ÈÄöËøá‰∏âÂ±ÇÊû∂ÊûÑÁöÑ S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºåÊÇ®Áé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•Â∞Ü ABAP ÂºÄÂèëÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºàADTÔºåÂú® Eclipse ‰∏≠ÔºâÁõ¥Êé•ËøûÊé•Âà∞Á≥ªÁªü„ÄÇÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÊµèËßàÂºÄÂèëÂØπË±°ÔºåÂåÖÊã¨ CDS ËßÜÂõæ„ÄÇÂàõÂª∫ ABAP Â≠òÂÇ®Â∫ìÊ†ëÂèØËÆ©ÊÇ®ÊåâÁªÑ‰ª∂ÂíåÂèëÂ∏ÉÁä∂ÊÄÅÊµèËßàÔºå‰ª•Êü•ÊâæÂ∑≤ÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑËßÜÂõæÁî®‰∫éÊÇ®ÁöÑÊâ©Â±ï„ÄÇ

 

ÊèêÈÜí‰∏Ä‰∏ãÔºå‰ªÄ‰πàÊòØ S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºü

S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºàÊàñÂÖ¨Êúâ CEÔºâÊòØ SAP ÁöÑ SaaS ERP„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰πãÂâçË¢´Áß∞‰∏∫ S/4HANA Cloud Âíå S/4HANA Public CloudÔºåËøôÁßç S/4 Âèò‰ΩìÂº∫Ë∞É‰∏éÊ†áÂáÜ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÁöÑÁ¥ßÂØÜÂ•ëÂêà„ÄÇËØ•Ëß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÁî± SAP ÊâòÁÆ°ÂíåÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÇÂè™ËÉΩËøõË°åÊ∏ÖÊ¥ÅÊ†∏ÂøÉÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÂçáÁ∫ßÊåâÁÖßÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥Ë°®ËøõË°å„ÄÇ

 

‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πà S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÂæàÈáçË¶ÅÔºü

ËôΩÁÑ∂ÊúÄÂ§ßÁöÑÂÆ¢Êà∑ÂæÄÂæÄÂú® SAP ‰∏ñÁïå‰∏≠ÊúÄÂèóÂÖ≥Ê≥®Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÊï∞ÈáèÊòØÊúâÈôêÁöÑ„ÄÇÂΩìÊÇ®Â∞ÜÁõÆÂÖâÊîæÂÆΩÂà∞ÂåÖÊã¨Ë∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ∞èÁöÑÂÆ¢Êà∑Êó∂Ôºå‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÊï∞Èáè‰ºöÊõ¥Âä†ÊòæËëó„ÄÇ

Êç¢Âè•ËØùËØ¥ÔºåÊã•Êúâ 10,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏ÊØîÊã•Êúâ 100,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏Â§öÂæóÂ§ö„ÄÇÊã•Êúâ 1,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏ÊØîÊã•Êúâ 10,000 ÂêçÂëòÂ∑•ÁöÑÂÖ¨Âè∏Â§öÂæóÂ§ö„ÄÇ

ËøôÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄÊÄªÂ∏ÇÂú∫ÊòØÂ∑®Â§ßÁöÑÔºåÂç≥‰ΩøÊØè‰∏™ÂçïÁã¨ÁöÑËÆ¢ÈòÖËæÉÂ∞è„ÄÇ

 

Âú®ÂÖ∂‰ªñÊù°‰ª∂Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåËøô‰∫õËæÉÂ∞èÁöÑÂÆ¢Êà∑Êõ¥ÂèØËÉΩÈÄâÊã©S/4HANAÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂØπ‰ªñ‰ª¨Êù•ËØ¥ÂèØËÉΩÊõ¥ÂÖ∑ÊàêÊú¨ÊïàÁõä„ÄÇ

ÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÔºåÊó†Ê≥ïÊâßË°å"ËÑè"Êâ©Â±ïÂíåÂ¢ûÂº∫Ôºå‰ª•ÂèäÊó†Ê≥ïÂÅúÁïôÂú®ËøáÊó∂ÁâàÊú¨‰∏äÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Ë¢´ËßÜ‰∏∫S/4HANAÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁöÑ‰ºòÂäø„ÄÇ

SAP ÁöÑÊÑøÊôØÊòØÈöèÁùÄÊó∂Èó¥ÁöÑÊé®ÁßªÔºåË∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ§öÁöÑÂÆ¢Êà∑Â∞ÜËΩ¨ÂêëS/4HANAÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠‰∏Ä‰∫õÂú®"Ê∏ÖÁêÜ"ÂÖ∂ÈÅóÁïôÂ¢ûÂº∫ÂêéËΩ¨Êç¢„ÄÇ

 

Êàë‰ª¨Â¶Ç‰ΩïÊâ©Â±ï S/4HANA ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁâàÔºü

ËôΩÁÑ∂ÈÄÇÂ∫îÊ†áÂáÜÊµÅÁ®ãÊòØÁõÆÊ†áÔºå‰ΩÜS/4HANAÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÂèØ‰ª•Âú®ÈúÄË¶ÅÊó∂ËøõË°åÊâ©Â±ïÂíåÂ¢ûÂº∫„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÊâ©Â±ïÊñπÂºèÂèØ‰ª•ÂàÜÁ±ª‰∏∫Ôºö

 

Â†ÜÊ†à‰∏äÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑Êâ©Â±ï

BTP ‰∏äÁöÑÂπ∂Ë°åÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÊûÑÂª∫Êâ©Â±ï

‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàÂë¢ÔºüÂõ†‰∏∫ÂèëÂ∏ÉËßÜÂõæÂØπ SAP Êù•ËØ¥ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰ª∂Â§ß‰∫ãÔºåÂÆÉ‰ª£Ë°®ÁùÄ‰øùÊåÅËØ•ËßÜÂõæÂèØÁî®ÂíåÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑÊâøËØ∫„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûú‰∏çÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑËØùÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÊâ©Â±ïÂèØËÉΩÂú®ÊØè‰∏™ÂçáÁ∫ßÂë®ÊúüÈÉΩ‰ºö‰∏≠Êñ≠ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Ê†áÂáÜËßÜÂõæÁöÑ‰øÆÊîπ„ÄÇËøôÂ∞ÜÂÆåÂÖ®ÈôêÂà∂S/4HANAÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁöÑÂèØË°åÊÄß„ÄÇ

Âú®Á¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™Â±èÂπïÔºàÂ≠òÂÇ®Â∫ìÊ†ëÂêëÂØºÔºâ‰∏äÔºåÈÄâÊã© Core Data Services„ÄÇ

entry.title: Handling $filter,$search and $orderby in SAP CAP when consuming External REST APIs
entry.content:
Introduction

When building applications with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), a very common real-world scenario is:

  • Your CAP service acts as a proxy
  • Data is fetched from an external REST API
  • The external API does not support OData

But your Fiori/UI5 frontend still sends OData queries like: 

$filter=country eq 'IN'&$search=Bangalore&$orderby=name desc

This blog explains how to handle OData query options like $filter, $search, and $orderby in SAP CAP Node.js when your service consumes a non-OData external REST API.

Here is a lightweight JavaScript utility (handleOData.js) that:

  • Interprets CAP‚Äôs query structure (req.query.SELECT)
  • Applies filtering logic directly on API responses
  • Adds full-text search capability
  • Supports dynamic sorting based on $orderby

With this approach, your Fiori/UI applications can continue using rich OData queries without any dependency on the external API.

This solution is ideal for building CAP-based proxy services on SAP BTP that integrate with legacy or third-party REST systems.

Problem Statement : 

Consider this scenario: Your frontend sends

GET /odata/v4/srv/DemandAreas?$filter=country eq 'IN'&$orderby=name asc

But your backend actually calls ,   

GET https://external.api/demandAreas

The external API:

  • Does not support $filter
  • Does not support $search
  • Does not support $orderby

Yet you still want your frontend to fully leverage OData features.

So how do we bridge this gap?

Architecture Overview:

Solution Overview: 

Utility file , handleOData.js exposes three main functions:

module.exports = { handleFilter, handleSearch, handleSort }

Each function handles a specific OData concept.

1. Handling $filter

CAP provides filters in a structured format (req.query.SELECT.where).

This utility interprets this structure and evaluates it against each result record.

Core logic idea:

function handleFilter(filters, item) {
  const stack = [];

  const applyComparison = (field, op, value) => {
    const fieldValue = item[field];

    switch (op) {
      case '=': return fieldValue == value;
      case '!=': return fieldValue != value;
      case '>': return fieldValue > value;
      case '>=': return fieldValue >= value;
      case '<': return fieldValue < value;
      case '<=': return fieldValue <= value;
      default: return false;
    }
  };

  // Logic continues to resolve AND / OR conditions}

This supports:

  • eq, ne, gt, ge, lt, le
  • Logical operations: AND, OR
  • Nested conditions

2. Handling $search

CAP exposes the search phrase via req.query.SELECT.search. The utility applies search across properties of each record.

Simplified logic:

function handleSearch(searchTerm, data) {
  return data.filter(item =>
    Object.values(item).some(val =>
      String(val).toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
    )
  );
}

This allows our Fiori/UI app to use for example , $search=Bangalore

Even if the external API has no search support at all.

3. Handling $orderby

Ordering is handled using CAP‚Äôs orderBy structure.

Logic overview:

function handleSort(req, result) {
  const [orderClause] = req.query.SELECT.orderBy;
  const field = orderClause.ref[0];
  const dir = orderClause.sort === 'desc' ? -1 : 1;

  return [...result].sort((a, b) =>
    a[field] > b[field] ? 1 * dir : -1 * dir
  );
}

Supported:

  • $orderby=name asc
  • $orderby=createdAt desc

CAP Service Integration Example

Below is how you can plug this into your service implementation file:

const { handleFilter, handleSearch, handleSort } = require('./code/handleOData');
module.exports = (srv) => {

  srv.on('READ', 'DemandAreas', async (req) => {

    // 1. Call external REST APIlet data = await fetchExternalData();

    // 2. Apply $filterif (req.query.SELECT.where) {
      data = data.filter(item => handleFilter(req.query.SELECT.where, item));
    }

    // 3. Apply $searchif (req.query.SELECT.search) {
      data = handleSearch(req.query.SELECT.search, data);
    }

    // 4. Apply $orderbyif (req.query.SELECT.orderBy) {
      data = handleSort(req, data);
    }

    return data;
  });
};

Benefits of this Approach

  • Clean separation between CAP and external REST API
  • Full OData filtering support for Fiori/UI apps
  • No dependency on the external service supporting OData
  • Plug-and-play in any Node.js CAP project
  • Easy to extend with more operators

Conclusion:

This utility helps bridge the gap between OData-driven applications and non-OData REST services, while keeping our CAP service clean and the UI fully functional. If you‚Äôre building similar integrations, I hope this helps accelerate your work.

entry.title: Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting - Enhancing Compliance Management
entry.content:
The Evolution of the Tax Function 

Not too long ago, multinational companies relied on a more local approach for managing tax compliance. Each country had its own dedicated tax expert, someone who truly understood the local regulations and handled everything from VAT returns to audit responses within their territory. This model worked well in many ways. It offered deep local knowledge and quick responsiveness when needed. However, it also came with its own set of challenges, especially around consistency, oversight, and cost. 

As businesses expanded and sought greater efficiency, many shifted towards a centralized model. Shared service centres were established to manage tax and statutory reporting across multiple countries from a single location. This transition brought clear advantages. Processes became more streamlined, control improved, and costs were reduced. At the same time, it introduced a new challenge, teams that previously focused on just one country were now responsible for a global compliance portfolio. 

In this new environment, shared service teams need tools that help them scale their efforts, automate routine tasks, and ensure consistency across regions. Mass Actions and Scheduling in Statutory Reporting address these challenges for global teams.  

The Accountant‚Äôs Daily Reality‚ÄîBefore and After 

Before these features, here is what a day looked like during the VAT season: 

  • Log in. 
  • Manually generate reports for each country. 
  • Review and validate them. 
  • Submit them one by one. 
  • Chase down approvals. 
  • Update submission statuses. 
  • Track what was accepted, what failed, and what needed to be resubmitted. 

Repeat this for 5 reports per country √ó 10 countries. That is 50 reporting tasks per month. 

Mass Actions 

With Mass Actions, we can now execute bulk actions across all reports in one go. The steps include: - 

  1. Selecting the reports we want. 
  2. Choosing the action - Generate, Send Report Run for Approval, Update Report Run Submission Status or Submit Report Run. 
  3. Hitting "Generate/Send/Update/Submit". 

SAP handles the rest. 

Need to manage reports for France, Norway, Columbia and Poland whenever the local regulations demand? Instead of processing each report manually and individually, Mass Actions allow Business users to handle all these requirements together by selecting the relevant reports, executing the needed steps, and letting the system take care of the rest.

 

Problem We are Solving 

With Mass actions we have 

  • Reduced Manual Effort 
  • Lower Operational Costs 
  • Increased Productivity 

Here is a simplified overview of a monthly VAT process flow using Mass Actions: 

 

1. Select Required Tasks

 

2. Choose Action - Generate Report Run

 

 

3. Execute Reporting Tasks in Bulk

 

4. Review Logs to track progress

With Mass actions we have: 

  •  Efficiency 

Save hours of manual, repetitive work with bulk processing capabilities. 

Streamline compliance activities across countries and report types from a single interface. 

  •  Scalability 

Easily manage a growing volume of reports 

Support centralized operations across multiple jurisdictions without additional overhead. 

  • Flexibility 

Adapt to various reporting requirements across entities, countries, and regulatory formats. 

Configure actions and schedules to fit both legal mandates and internal business timelines. 

To Summarize 

Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting provides a practical way to manage large volumes of statutory reports efficiently. They enable centralized processing, reduce manual effort, and ensure that recurring tasks run reliably in the background helping organizations stay compliant across multiple countries and reporting cycles. 

The follow-up section of this blog, which explores the Scheduling feature of Run Statutory Reporting, is available via the link provided below.

 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/mass-actions-in-statutory-reporting-part-2-scheduling-for-timely-execution/ba-p/14273540

entry.title: Mass Actions in Statutory Reporting ‚Äì Part 2: Scheduling for Timely Execution
entry.content:
Introduction 

In the previous blog, we explored how Mass Actions simplify statutory reporting by allowing users to perform a single action across multiple tasks. This feature reduces manual effort across tasks. 

Among the available options, Schedule Mass Action adds even more value by letting users automate actions to run at a specific time aligned with reporting deadlines. In this follow-up, we will dive into how scheduling ensures timely compliance in your reporting process. 

Let us take a closer look at how to set it up and make the most of it. 

Scheduling Mass Actions. 

Let us say we want to generate all monthly VAT reports on the 1st of every month, review them on the 2nd, and submit them by the 5th. We set this up once, and it runs like clockwork. 

Even when employees are away or simply overseeing the process, reports continue to generate and queue automatically in the background. The system knows. 

The scheduling process flow follows three targeted steps: 

1. Choose the required Job Template ‚Äì 
Choose a job template and assign a clear job name for easy identification. It works on two scheduling modes: 

a.‚ÄØ Schedule reporting actions to recur on fixed calendar dates: Ideal for known deadlines (e.g., 1st of every month). 

b.‚ÄØ Schedule reporting action to recur per period based on different reporting deadlines: Perfect for fiscal cycles or quarterly returns. 

‚ÄØ 

This dual-template approach exists to accommodate the different reporting rhythms and regulatory requirements faced by multinational organizations. 

2. Scheduling Options 
Define a start date/time, an optional end date, and a recurrence pattern (e.g., monthly, quarterly). 

3. Set the required parameters 
Specify essential details such as the reporting entity, report type, or period - tailored to your use case. 

Once scheduled, your reports run automatically. Users can focus on higher-value activities, knowing compliance processing happens reliably in the background. 

With Scheduling, we can now: 

  • Ensures Timely Submissions 

Schedules actions to run at the right time, helping meet reporting deadlines without manual effort. 

  • Reduces Manual Workload 

Eliminates the need to trigger actions manually, especially useful for recurring or large-volume reports. 

  • Improves Efficiency and Planning 

Allows users to plan by scheduling tasks in advance, reducing last-minute pressure. 

 

To summarize 

Scheduling in Mass Actions allows users to automate statutory reporting tasks based on specific timelines. Instead of executing actions like Generate, Submit, or Approve immediately, users can schedule them to run at a future date and time, often aligned with reporting deadlines. This is especially useful when managing recurring or time-sensitive reports across multiple entities or periods. 

Hope after reading this blog post it will provide some useful insights about the features ‚Äì Mass Actions & Scheduling. Feel free to provide your feedback, suggestions, questions in comments below.

entry.title: Triggering onboarding notifications based on candidates‚Äô input during the Onboarding ADC
entry.content:
Email services is one of the features used in SuccessFactors onboarding to trigger different

types of notifications to the external candidates and internal active users. SAP offers standard email triggers in onboarding which can be turned on/off based on the customers' requirements. In some cases, customers may want to trigger the notifications based on certain conditions as well.

The condition is triggering the notification to recruitment team when candidate opt in for health declaration during additional data collection step, which should be triggered only after candidate completes the Compliance form signature as it is last step of onboarding process by candidate. Onboarding supports this feature by setting up a filter business rule which validates what candidate has entered as an input during additional data collection step.

Customer pain point:

Customer had difficulty in identifying which onboarding candidate has opted in for a health declaration to make the necessary arrangements prior to their company joining date.

Prerequisites:

  • Access to Email Services
  • Access to Configure Business Rules

Configurations:

Create a Notification template with suitable content in (ONB) Compliance Document Flow Message Category.

In this case, the notification template is created from standard template √† (ONB) Compliance Document Signature task completion Template 

 

Note: Email category can be selected according to the requirement at when or what step the notification should be triggered and the notification templates can be cloned from the existing standard notification templates, like it‚Äôs done in this scenario.

Create the Filter Email Template Scenario Business rule to trigger the notification only when Health declaration in Additional Data Collection step is selected as ‚ÄòYes‚Äô by the candidate.

Add the created business in the Filter Business Rules field.

Expected result:

When the candidate selects ‚ÄòYes‚Äô for health declaration questionnaire during additional data collection step. The notification will be triggered to the Recruitment team.

Health declaration notification trigger when candidate opts in for Health declaration.

entry.title: How I Began My SAP SuccessFactors Compensation Journey
entry.content:
In July 2024, I began my journey in SAP SuccessFactors Compensation. I started as a Trainee Analyst, going through the SAP Compensation Implementation Guide and testing functionalities in the demo system. Initially, I thought building a Compensation template was straightforward but real projects quickly proved that unexpected challenges are a part of everyday work.

Over time, I worked on multiple real-time support projects. Since these involved existing templates, most of my tasks focused on updating configurations based on new requirements. Even then, I faced several complex issues that forced me to think deeply and learn continuously. I‚Äôve also been part of implementation projects where the problems required careful observation, functional clarity, and precise thinking.

I‚Äôm writing this blog to document my growth as a consultant. Starting this week, I‚Äôll publish a new blog every Monday. I‚Äôll share the problems I encounter, the solutions that work, and the lessons I learn both technical and functional. If there‚Äôs one thing experience has taught me, it‚Äôs that technical configuration matters, but functional understanding matters just as much, if not more.

I‚Äôve gained a lot from the SAP Community, and now I feel it‚Äôs time to give back.

Special thanks to @xavierlegarrec for those insightful blogs and keeping the community updated.

SAP SuccessFactors Compensation
